imports.value: A_UNDERLINE, A_REVERSE, A_LEFTLINE, A_CHARTEXT, A_ALTCHARSET, COLOR_PAIR, A_RIGHTLINE, A_ITALIC, A_DIM, A_BLINK, A_STRIKEOUT, A_OVERLINE, A_INVIS, A_BOLD

attributes.value: allow(non_camel_case_types, non_snake_case)

defs.name: Input
defs.value:
pub enum Input {
    Character(char),
    Unknown(i32),
    KeyCodeYes,
    KeyBreak,
    KeyDown,
    KeyUp,
    KeyLeft,
    KeyRight,
    KeyHome,
    KeyBackspace,
    KeyF0,
    KeyF1,
    KeyF2,
    KeyF3,
    KeyF4,
    KeyF5,
    KeyF6,
    KeyF7,
    KeyF8,
    KeyF9,
    KeyF10,
    KeyF11,
    KeyF12,
    KeyF13,
    KeyF14,
    KeyF15,
    KeyDL,
    KeyIL,
    KeyDC,
    KeyIC,
    KeyEIC,
    KeyClear,
    KeyEOS,
    KeyEOL,
    KeySF,
    KeySR,
    KeyNPage,
    KeyPPage,
    KeySTab,
    KeyCTab,
    KeyCATab,
    KeyEnter,
    KeySReset,
    KeyReset,
    KeyPrint,
    KeyLL,
    KeyAbort,
    KeySHelp,
    KeyLHelp,
    KeyBTab,
    KeyBeg,
    KeyCancel,
    KeyClose,
    KeyCommand,
    KeyCopy,
    KeyCreate,
    KeyEnd,
    KeyExit,
    KeyFind,
    KeyHelp,
    KeyMark,
    KeyMessage,
    KeyMove,
    KeyNext,
    KeyOpen,
    KeyOptions,
    KeyPrevious,
    KeyRedo,
    KeyReference,
    KeyRefresh,
    KeyReplace,
    KeyRestart,
    KeyResume,
    KeySave,
    KeySBeg,
    KeySCancel,
    KeySCommand,
    KeySCopy,
    KeySCreate,
    KeySDC,
    KeySDL,
    KeySelect,
    KeySEnd,
    KeySEOL,
    KeySExit,
    KeySFind,
    KeySHome,
    KeySIC,
    KeySLeft,
    KeySMessage,
    KeySMove,
    KeySNext,
    KeySOptions,
    KeySPrevious,
    KeySPrint,
    KeySRedo,
    KeySReplace,
    KeySRight,
    KeySResume,
    KeySSave,
    KeySSuspend,
    KeySUndo,
    KeySuspend,
    KeyUndo,
    KeyResize,
    KeyEvent,
    KeyMouse,
    KeyA1,
    KeyA3,
    KeyB2,
    KeyC1,
    KeyC3,
}

defs.name: Attribute
defs.value:
pub enum Attribute {
    AlternativeCharSet,
    Bold,
    Blink,
    CharText,
    Dim,
    Leftline,
    Invisible,
    Italic,
    Normal,
    Overline,
    Reverse,
    Rightline,
    Strikeout,
    Underline,
}

defs.name: addch
defs.value: pub fn addch<T: ToChtype>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Adds the chtype ch to the window at the current cursor position, and advances the cursor.

attributes.value: / Adds the chtype ch to the window at the current cursor position, and advances the cursor.
/ Note that chtypes can convey both text (a single character) and attributes, including a
/ color pair.

defs.name: addstr
defs.value: pub fn addstr<T: AsRef<str>>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Write all the characters of the string to the given window.

attributes.value: / Write all the characters of the string to the given window.
/ The functionality is similar to calling window.addch() once for each character in the
/ string.

defs.name: addnstr
defs.value: pub fn addnstr<T: AsRef<str>>(&Self, T, usize) -> i32
defs.docs:
Write at most length characters; if length is negative, then the entire string will be
 added.

attributes.value: / Write at most length characters; if length is negative, then the entire string will be
/ added.

defs.name: attrget
defs.docs: Retrieve attributes for the given window.

attributes.value: / Retrieve attributes for the given window.
/ ```rust
/ use pancurses::{A_BOLD, initscr, endwin};
/ let window = initscr();
/ window.attron(A_BOLD);
/ let (active_attributes, color_pair) = window.attrget();
/ assert_eq!(A_BOLD, active_attributes);
/ endwin();

defs.name: attroff
defs.value: pub fn attroff<T: Into<chtype>>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Turns off the named attributes without affecting any other attributes.

attributes.value: / Turns off the named attributes without affecting any other attributes.

defs.name: attron
defs.value: pub fn attron<T: Into<chtype>>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Turns on the named attributes without affecting any other attributes.

attributes.value: / Turns on the named attributes without affecting any other attributes.

defs.name: attrset
defs.value: pub fn attrset<T: Into<chtype>>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Sets the current attributes of the given window to attributes.

attributes.value: / Sets the current attributes of the given window to attributes.

defs.name: bkgd
defs.value: pub fn bkgd<T: Into<chtype>>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Not only change the background, but apply it immediately to every cell in the window.

attributes.value: / Not only change the background, but apply it immediately to every cell in the window.

defs.name: bkgdset
defs.docs:
Manipulate the background of a window. The background is a chtype consisting of any
 combination of attributes and a character; it is combined with each chtype added or
 inserted to the window by addch() or insch(). Only the attribute part is used to set
 the background of non-blank characters, while both character and attributes are used
 for blank positions.

attributes.value: / Manipulate the background of a window. The background is a chtype consisting of any
/ combination of attributes and a character; it is combined with each chtype added or
/ inserted to the window by addch() or insch(). Only the attribute part is used to set
/ the background of non-blank characters, while both character and attributes are used
/ for blank positions.

defs.name: border
defs.value: pub fn border<T: ToChtype>(&Self, T, T, T, T, T, T, T, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Draw a border around the edges of the window.

attributes.value: / Draw a border around the edges of the window.

defs.name: chgat
defs.value: pub fn chgat(&Self, i32, chtype, i16) -> i32
defs.docs:
Changes the attributes of a given number of characters starting at the current cursor
 location. It does not update the cursor and does not perform wrapping. A character count
 of -1 or greater than the remaining window width means to change attributes all the way
 to the end of the current line.

attributes.value: / Changes the attributes of a given number of characters starting at the current cursor
/ location. It does not update the cursor and does not perform wrapping. A character count
/ of -1 or greater than the remaining window width means to change attributes all the way
/ to the end of the current line.

defs.name: clear
defs.docs:
Similar to erase(), but also calls clearok() to ensure that the the window is cleared on
 the next refresh().

attributes.value: / Similar to erase(), but also calls clearok() to ensure that the the window is cleared on
/ the next refresh().

defs.name: clearok
defs.docs:
With clearok(), if bf is TRUE, the next call to refresh() with
 this window will clear the screen completely and redraw the
 entire screen.

attributes.value: / With clearok(), if bf is TRUE, the next call to refresh() with
/ this window will clear the screen completely and redraw the
/ entire screen.

defs.name: clrtobot
defs.docs: Clear the window from the current cursor position to the end of the window.

attributes.value: / Clear the window from the current cursor position to the end of the window.

defs.name: clrtoeol
defs.docs: Clear the window from the current cursor position to the end of the current line.

attributes.value: / Clear the window from the current cursor position to the end of the current line.

defs.name: color_set
defs.docs:
Sets the current color of the given window to the foreground/background combination
 described by the color pair parameter.

attributes.value: / Sets the current color of the given window to the foreground/background combination
/ described by the color pair parameter.

defs.name: copywin
defs.value: pub fn copywin(&Self, &Window, i32, i32, i32, i32, i32, i32, bool) -> i32
defs.docs:
Copy all text from this window to the destination window. The arguments src_tc and
 src_tr specify the top left corner of the region to be copied. dst_tc, dst_tr, dst_br,
 and dst_bc specify the region within the destination window to copy to. The argument
 "overlay", if TRUE, indicates that the copy is done non-destructively (as in overlay());
 blanks in the source window are not copied to the destination window. When overlay is
 FALSE, blanks are copied.

attributes.value: / Copy all text from this window to the destination window. The arguments src_tc and
/ src_tr specify the top left corner of the region to be copied. dst_tc, dst_tr, dst_br,
/ and dst_bc specify the region within the destination window to copy to. The argument
/ "overlay", if TRUE, indicates that the copy is done non-destructively (as in overlay());
/ blanks in the source window are not copied to the destination window. When overlay is
/ FALSE, blanks are copied.

defs.name: delch
defs.docs:
Delete the character under the cursor. All characters to the right of the cursor
 on the same line are moved to the left one position and hte last character on the
 line is filled with a blank. The cursor position does not change.

attributes.value: / Delete the character under the cursor. All characters to the right of the cursor
/ on the same line are moved to the left one position and hte last character on the
/ line is filled with a blank. The cursor position does not change.

defs.name: deleteln
defs.docs:
Delete the line under the cursor. All lines below are moved up one line, and the
 bottom line is cleared. The cursor position does not change.

attributes.value: / Delete the line under the cursor. All lines below are moved up one line, and the
/ bottom line is cleared. The cursor position does not change.

defs.name: delwin
defs.docs:
Deletes the window, freeing all associated memory. In the case of overlapping windows,
 subwindows should be deleted before the main window.

attributes.value: / Deletes the window, freeing all associated memory. In the case of overlapping windows,
/ subwindows should be deleted before the main window.

defs.name: derwin
defs.value: pub fn derwin(&Self, i32, i32, i32, i32) -> Result<Window, i32>
defs.docs:
The same as subwin(), except that begy and begx are relative to the origin of the window
 rather than the screen.

attributes.value: / The same as subwin(), except that begy and begx are relative to the origin of the window
/ rather than the screen.
/ There is no difference between subwindows and derived windows.

defs.name: draw_box
defs.value: pub fn draw_box<T: ToChtype>(&Self, T, T) -> i32
defs.docs:
Draw a border around the edge of the window. If any argument is zero, an appropriate
 default is used.

attributes.value: / Draw a border around the edge of the window. If any argument is zero, an appropriate
/ default is used.

defs.name: dupwin
defs.docs: Creates an exact duplicate of the window.

attributes.value: / Creates an exact duplicate of the window.

defs.name: enclose
defs.value: pub fn enclose(&Self, i32, i32) -> bool
defs.docs: Reports whether the given screen-relative y, x coordinates fall within the window.

attributes.value: / Reports whether the given screen-relative y, x coordinates fall within the window.

defs.name: erase
defs.docs: Copies blanks (i.e. the background chtype) to every cell of the window.

attributes.value: / Copies blanks (i.e. the background chtype) to every cell of the window.

defs.name: get_beg_y
defs.docs: Get the upper-left y coordinate of this window

attributes.value: / Get the upper-left y coordinate of this window

defs.name: get_beg_yx
defs.docs: Get the upper-left y and x coordinates of this window

attributes.value: / Get the upper-left y and x coordinates of this window

defs.name: getbkgd
defs.docs: Returns the given window's current background character and attributes.

attributes.value: / Returns the given window's current background character and attributes.

defs.name: getch
defs.docs: Read a character from the terminal associated with the window.

attributes.value: / Read a character from the terminal associated with the window.
/ In nodelay mode, if there is no input waiting, None is returned. In delay mode,
/ the program will hang until the system  passes text through to the program. Depending on
/ the setting of cbreak(), this will be after one character or after the first newline.
/ Unless noecho() has been set, the character will also be echoed into the designated window.
/ If keypad() is TRUE, and a function key is pressed, the token for that function key will be
/ returned instead of the raw characters.
/ If nodelay(win, TRUE) has been called on the window and no input is waiting, None is
/ returned.

defs.name: get_cur_x
defs.docs: Return the current x coordinate of the cursor

attributes.value: / Return the current x coordinate of the cursor

defs.name: get_cur_y
defs.docs: Return the current y coordinate of the cursor

attributes.value: / Return the current y coordinate of the cursor

defs.name: get_cur_yx
defs.docs: Return the current y and x coordinates of the cursor

attributes.value: / Return the current y and x coordinates of the cursor

defs.name: get_max_x
defs.docs: Return the maximum x value of this Window, in other words the number of columns.

attributes.value: / Return the maximum x value of this Window, in other words the number of columns.

defs.name: get_max_y
defs.docs: Return the maximum y value of this Window, in other words the number of rows.

attributes.value: / Return the maximum y value of this Window, in other words the number of rows.

defs.name: get_max_yx
defs.docs: Return the maximum y and x value of this Window

attributes.value: / Return the maximum y and x value of this Window

defs.name: hline
defs.value: pub fn hline<T: ToChtype>(&Self, T, i32) -> i32
defs.docs:
Draw a horizontal line using ch from the current cursor position. The line is at most
 n characters long, or as many as fit into the window.

attributes.value: / Draw a horizontal line using ch from the current cursor position. The line is at most
/ n characters long, or as many as fit into the window.

defs.name: insdelln
defs.docs:
For positive n, insert n lines into the specified window above the current line.
 The n bottom lines are lost. For negative n, delete n lines (starting with the one under
 the cursor), and move the remaining lines up. The bottom n lines are cleared.
 The current cursor position remains the same.

attributes.value: / For positive n, insert n lines into the specified window above the current line.
/ The n bottom lines are lost. For negative n, delete n lines (starting with the one under
/ the cursor), and move the remaining lines up. The bottom n lines are cleared.
/ The current cursor position remains the same.

defs.name: insertln
defs.docs: A blank line is inserted above the current line and the bottom line is lost.

attributes.value: / A blank line is inserted above the current line and the bottom line is lost.

defs.name: is_linetouched
defs.docs:
Returns true if the specified line in the specified window has been changed since the last
 call to refresh().

attributes.value: / Returns true if the specified line in the specified window has been changed since the last
/ call to refresh().

defs.name: is_touched
defs.docs: Returns true if the specified window has been changed since the last call to refresh().

attributes.value: / Returns true if the specified window has been changed since the last call to refresh().

defs.name: keypad
defs.docs:
Controls whether getch() returns function/special keys as single key codes (e.g., the left
 arrow key as KEY_LEFT).

attributes.value: / Controls whether getch() returns function/special keys as single key codes (e.g., the left
/ arrow key as KEY_LEFT).
/ Per X/Open, the default for keypad mode is OFF. You'll probably want it on. With keypad
/ mode off, if a special key is pressed, getch() does nothing or returns ERR.

defs.name: insch
defs.value: pub fn insch<T: ToChtype>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Insert the character ch before the character under the cursor.

attributes.value: / Insert the character ch before the character under the cursor.
/ All characters to the right of the cursor are moved one space to the right, with the
/ possibility of the rightmost character on the line being lost. The insertion operation does
/ not change the cursor position.

defs.name: mouse_trafo
defs.value: pub fn mouse_trafo(&Self, i32, i32, bool) -> (i32, i32)
defs.docs: Converts between screen-relative and window-relative coordinates.

attributes.value: / Converts between screen-relative and window-relative coordinates.
/ A to_screen parameter of true means to convert from window to screen;
/ otherwise the reverse.

defs.name: mv
defs.value: pub fn mv(&Self, i32, i32) -> i32
defs.docs: The cursor associated with the window is moved to the given location.

attributes.value: / The cursor associated with the window is moved to the given location.
/ This does not move the physical cursor of the terminal until refresh() is called.  The
/ position specified is relative to the upper left corner of the window, which is (0,0).

defs.name: mvaddch
defs.value: pub fn mvaddch<T: ToChtype>(&Self, i32, i32, T) -> i32
defs.docs: moves the cursor to the specified position and adds ch to the specified window

attributes.value: / moves the cursor to the specified position and adds ch to the specified window

defs.name: mvaddstr
defs.value: pub fn mvaddstr<T: AsRef<str>>(&Self, i32, i32, T) -> i32
defs.docs:
Write all the characters of the string str to the given window. The functionality is
 similar to calling waddch() once for each character in the string.

attributes.value: / Write all the characters of the string str to the given window. The functionality is
/ similar to calling waddch() once for each character in the string.

defs.name: mvaddnstr
defs.value: pub fn mvaddnstr<T: AsRef<str>>(&Self, i32, i32, T, i32) -> i32
defs.docs: Write the first'n' characters of the string str to the given window.

attributes.value: / Write the first'n' characters of the string str to the given window.

defs.name: mvchgat
defs.value: pub fn mvchgat(&Self, i32, i32, i32, chtype, i16) -> i32
defs.docs:
Moves the cursor and changes the attributes of a given number of characters starting at the
 cursor location. It does not update the cursor and does not perform wrapping. A character count
 of -1 or greater than the remaining window width means to change attributes all the way
 to the end of the current line.

attributes.value: / Moves the cursor and changes the attributes of a given number of characters starting at the
/ cursor location. It does not update the cursor and does not perform wrapping. A character count
/ of -1 or greater than the remaining window width means to change attributes all the way
/ to the end of the current line.

defs.name: mvderwin
defs.value: pub fn mvderwin(&Self, i32, i32) -> i32
defs.docs: Moves a derived window (or subwindow) inside its parent window.

attributes.value: / Moves a derived window (or subwindow) inside its parent window.
/ The screen-relative parameters of the window are not changed. This routine is used to
/ display different parts of the parent window at the same physical position on the screen.

defs.name: mvinch
defs.value: pub fn mvinch(&Self, i32, i32) -> chtype
defs.docs:
Retrieves the character and attribute from the specified window position, in the form of a
 chtype.

attributes.value: / Retrieves the character and attribute from the specified window position, in the form of a
/ chtype.

defs.name: mvinsch
defs.value: pub fn mvinsch<T: ToChtype>(&Self, i32, i32, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Move the cursor and then insert the character ch before the character under the cursor.

attributes.value: / Move the cursor and then insert the character ch before the character under the cursor.
/ First performs a cursor movement using wmove, and returns an error if the position is
/ outside the window. All characters to the right of the cursor are moved one space to the
/ right, with the possibility of the rightmost character on the line being lost. The insertion
/ operation does not change the cursor position.

defs.name: mvprintw
defs.value: pub fn mvprintw<T: AsRef<str>>(&Self, i32, i32, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Add a string to the window at the specified cursor position.

attributes.value: / Add a string to the window at the specified cursor position.

defs.name: mvwin
defs.value: pub fn mvwin(&Self, i32, i32) -> i32
defs.docs: Moves the window so that the upper left-hand corner is at position (y,x).

attributes.value: / Moves the window so that the upper left-hand corner is at position (y,x).
/ If the move would cause the window to be off the screen, it is an error and the window is
/ not moved. Moving subwindows is allowed.

defs.name: nodelay
defs.docs:
Controls whether wgetch() is a non-blocking call. If the option is enabled, and
 no input is ready, wgetch() will return ERR. If disabled, wgetch() will hang until input is
 ready.

attributes.value: / Controls whether wgetch() is a non-blocking call. If the option is enabled, and
/ no input is ready, wgetch() will return ERR. If disabled, wgetch() will hang until input is
/ ready.

defs.name: noutrefresh
defs.docs: Copies the window to the virtual screen.

attributes.value: / Copies the window to the virtual screen.

defs.name: overlay
defs.docs:
Overlays this window on top of destination_window. This window and destination_window are
 not required to be the same size; only text where the two windows overlap is copied.
 overlay() is non-destructive.

attributes.value: / Overlays this window on top of destination_window. This window and destination_window are
/ not required to be the same size; only text where the two windows overlap is copied.
/ overlay() is non-destructive.

defs.name: overwrite
defs.docs:
Overlays this window on top of destination_window. This window and destination_window are
 not required to be the same size; only text where the two windows overlap is copied.
 overwrite() is destructive.

attributes.value: / Overlays this window on top of destination_window. This window and destination_window are
/ not required to be the same size; only text where the two windows overlap is copied.
/ overwrite() is destructive.

defs.name: printw
defs.value: pub fn printw<T: AsRef<str>>(&Self, T) -> i32
defs.docs: Add a string to the window at the current cursor position.

attributes.value: / Add a string to the window at the current cursor position.

defs.name: refresh
defs.docs:
Copies the named window to the physical terminal screen, taking into account what
 is already there in order to optimize cursor movement.

attributes.value: / Copies the named window to the physical terminal screen, taking into account what
/ is already there in order to optimize cursor movement.
/ This function must be called to get any output on the terminal, as other routines only
/ manipulate data structures. Unless leaveok() has been enabled, the physical cursor of the
/ terminal is left at the location of the window's cursor.

defs.name: scrollok
defs.docs:
If enabled and a scrolling region is set with setscrreg(), any attempt to move off
 the bottom margin will cause all lines in the scrolling region to scroll up one line.

attributes.value: / If enabled and a scrolling region is set with setscrreg(), any attempt to move off
/ the bottom margin will cause all lines in the scrolling region to scroll up one line.

defs.name: setscrreg
defs.value: pub fn setscrreg(&Self, i32, i32) -> i32
defs.docs: Sets a scrolling region in a window.

attributes.value: / Sets a scrolling region in a window.
/ "top" and "bot" are the line numbers for the top and bottom margins.

defs.name: subwin
defs.value: pub fn subwin(&Self, i32, i32, i32, i32) -> Result<Window, i32>
defs.docs: Creates a new subwindow within a window.

attributes.value: / Creates a new subwindow within a window.
/ The dimensions of the subwindow are nlines lines and ncols columns. The subwindow is at
/ position (begy, begx) on the screen. This position is relative to the screen, and not to
/ the window orig. Changes made to either window will affect both. When using this routine,
/ you will often need to call touchwin() before calling refresh().

defs.name: timeout
defs.docs: Set blocking or non-blocking reads for the specified window.

attributes.value: / Set blocking or non-blocking reads for the specified window.
/ The delay is measured in milliseconds. If it's negative, a blocking read is used; if zero,
/ then non-blocking reads are done -- if no input is waiting, ERR is returned immediately.
/ If the delay is positive, the read blocks for the delay period; if the period expires,
/ ERR is returned.

defs.name: touch
defs.docs:
Throws away all information about which parts of the window have been touched, pretending
 that the entire window has been drawn on.

attributes.value: / Throws away all information about which parts of the window have been touched, pretending
/ that the entire window has been drawn on.
/  This is sometimes necessary when using overlapping windows, since a change to one window
/ will affect the other window, but the records of which lines have been changed in the other
/ window will not reflect the change.

defs.name: touchline
defs.value: pub fn touchline(&Self, i32, i32) -> i32
defs.docs:
Throws away all information about which parts of the window have been touched, pretending
 that the entire window has been drawn on.

attributes.value: / Throws away all information about which parts of the window have been touched, pretending
/ that the entire window has been drawn on.
/  This is sometimes necessary when using overlapping windows, since a change to one window
/ will affect the other window, but the records of which lines have been changed in the other
/ window will not reflect the change.

defs.name: touchln
defs.value: pub fn touchln(&Self, i32, i32, bool) -> i32
defs.docs:
Makes n lines in the window, starting at line y, look as if they have or have not been
 changed since the last call to refresh().

attributes.value: / Makes n lines in the window, starting at line y, look as if they have or have not been
/ changed since the last call to refresh().

defs.name: ungetch
defs.docs: Places ch back onto the input queue to be returned by the next call to getch().

attributes.value: / Places ch back onto the input queue to be returned by the next call to getch().

defs.name: untouch
defs.docs: Marks all lines in the window as unchanged since the last call to refresh().

attributes.value: / Marks all lines in the window as unchanged since the last call to refresh().

defs.name: vline
defs.value: pub fn vline<T: ToChtype>(&Self, T, i32) -> i32
defs.docs:
Draw a vertical line using ch from the current cursor position. The line is at most
 n characters long, or as many as fit into the window.

attributes.value: / Draw a vertical line using ch from the current cursor position. The line is at most
/ n characters long, or as many as fit into the window.

defs.name: baudrate
defs.docs: Return the output speed of the terminal. On Windows it simply returns `INT_MAX`

attributes.value: / Return the output speed of the terminal. On Windows it simply returns `INT_MAX`

defs.name: beep
defs.docs: Sounds the audible bell on the terminal, if possible; if not, it calls flash().

attributes.value: / Sounds the audible bell on the terminal, if possible; if not, it calls flash().

defs.name: can_change_color
defs.docs: Indicates if the terminal has the capability to change the definition of its colors.

attributes.value: / Indicates if the terminal has the capability to change the definition of its colors.

defs.name: cbreak
defs.docs: Set cbreak mode.

attributes.value: / Set cbreak mode.
/ In cbreak mode, characters typed by the user are made available immediately, and erase/kill
/ character processing is not performed.  In nocbreak mode, typed characters are buffered until
/ a newline or carriage return. Interrupt and flow control characters are unaffected by this
/ mode.

defs.name: COLORS
defs.docs: Maximum number of colors the terminal is capable of displaying.

attributes.value: / Maximum number of colors the terminal is capable of displaying.

defs.name: COLOR_PAIRS
defs.docs: Maximum number of color-pairs the terminal is capable of displaying.

attributes.value: / Maximum number of color-pairs the terminal is capable of displaying.

defs.name: color_content
defs.docs:
This routine gives programmers a way to find the intensity of the red, green, and blue (RGB)
 components in a color. It takes the color number as an argument and returns three values
 that tell you the amounts of red, green, and blue components in the given color. The argument
 must be a legal color value, i.e., 0 through COLORS()-1, inclusive. The values that are returned
 are in the range 0 (no component) through 1000 (maximum amount of component), inclusive.

attributes.value: / This routine gives programmers a way to find the intensity of the red, green, and blue (RGB)
/ components in a color. It takes the color number as an argument and returns three values
/ that tell you the amounts of red, green, and blue components in the given color. The argument
/ must be a legal color value, i.e., 0 through COLORS()-1, inclusive. The values that are returned
/ are in the range 0 (no component) through 1000 (maximum amount of component), inclusive.
/ ```rust
/ use pancurses::{can_change_color, color_content, endwin, init_color, initscr, start_color};
/ initscr();
/ start_color();
/ if can_change_color() {
/     let (r, g, b) = color_content(8);
/     assert_eq!(35, r);
/     assert_eq!(502, g);
/     assert_eq!(1000, b);
/ endwin();

defs.name: curs_set
defs.docs: Alters the appearance of the cursor.

attributes.value: / Alters the appearance of the cursor.
/ A visibility of 0 makes it disappear; 1 makes it appear "normal" (usually an underline) and 2
/ makes it "highly visible" (usually a block).

defs.name: def_prog_mode
defs.docs:
Save the current terminal modes as the "program" (in curses) state for use by the
 `reset_prog_mode()` and `reset_shell_mode()` functions.  This is done automatically by initscr().

attributes.value: / Save the current terminal modes as the "program" (in curses) state for use by the
/ `reset_prog_mode()` and `reset_shell_mode()` functions.  This is done automatically by initscr().

defs.name: def_shell_mode
defs.docs:
Save the current terminal modes as the "shell" (not in curses) state for use by the
 `reset_prog_mode()` and `reset_shell_mode()` functions.  This is done automatically by initscr().

attributes.value: / Save the current terminal modes as the "shell" (not in curses) state for use by the
/ `reset_prog_mode()` and `reset_shell_mode()` functions.  This is done automatically by initscr().

defs.name: delay_output
defs.docs:
Inserts an 'milliseconds' millisecond pause in output. This routine should not be used extensively
 because padding characters are used rather than a CPU pause. If no padding character is
 specified, this uses napms to perform the delay.

attributes.value: / Inserts an 'milliseconds' millisecond pause in output. This routine should not be used extensively
/ because padding characters are used rather than a CPU pause. If no padding character is
/ specified, this uses napms to perform the delay.

defs.name: delscreen
defs.docs: Frees storage associated with the SCREEN data structure.

attributes.value: / Frees storage associated with the SCREEN data structure.
/ The endwin routine does not do this, so delscreen should be called after endwin if a particular
/ SCREEN is no longer needed.
/ In PDCurses, the parameter must be the value of SP, and delscreen() sets SP to NULL.

defs.name: doupdate
defs.docs:
Compares the virtual screen to the physical screen and performs an update of the physical
 screen.

attributes.value: / Compares the virtual screen to the physical screen and performs an update of the physical
/ screen.

defs.name: echo
defs.docs: Enabled echoing typed characters.

attributes.value: / Enabled echoing typed characters.
/ Initially, input characters are echoed. Subsequent calls to echo() and noecho() do not flush
/ type-ahead.

defs.name: endwin
defs.docs: Should be called before exiting or escaping from curses mode temporarily.

attributes.value: / Should be called before exiting or escaping from curses mode temporarily.
/ It will restore tty modes, move the cursor to the lower left corner of the screen and reset the
/ terminal into the proper non-visual mode.  To resume curses after a temporary escape, call
/ refresh() or doupdate().

defs.name: flash
defs.docs: Flashes the screen, if possible; if not, it calls beep().

attributes.value: / Flashes the screen, if possible; if not, it calls beep().

defs.name: flushinp
defs.docs:
Throws away any type-ahead that has been typed by the user and has not yet been read by the
 program.

attributes.value: / Throws away any type-ahead that has been typed by the user and has not yet been read by the
/ program.

defs.name: getmouse
defs.docs: Returns the current mouse status in an MEVENT struct.

attributes.value: / Returns the current mouse status in an MEVENT struct.

defs.name: half_delay
defs.docs: Similar to cbreak(), but allows for a time limit to be specified, in tenths of a second.

attributes.value: / Similar to cbreak(), but allows for a time limit to be specified, in tenths of a second.
/ This causes getch() to block for that period before returning None if no key has been received.
/ tenths must be between 1 and 255.

defs.name: has_colors
defs.docs: Indicates if the terminal supports, and can maniplulate color.

attributes.value: / Indicates if the terminal supports, and can maniplulate color.

defs.name: initscr
defs.docs: Initialize the curses system, this must be the first function that is called.

attributes.value: / Initialize the curses system, this must be the first function that is called.
/ Returns a Window struct that is used to access Window specific functions.

defs.name: init_color
defs.value: pub fn init_color(i16, i16, i16, i16) -> i32
defs.docs:
Changes the definition of a color. It takes four arguments: the number of the color to be
 changed followed by three RGB values (for the amounts of red, green, and blue components).
 The first argument must be a legal color value; default colors are not allowed here.
 Each of the last three arguments must be a value in the range 0 through 1000. When `init_color`
 is used, all occurrences of that color on the screen immediately change to the new definition.

attributes.value: / Changes the definition of a color. It takes four arguments: the number of the color to be
/ changed followed by three RGB values (for the amounts of red, green, and blue components).
/ The first argument must be a legal color value; default colors are not allowed here.
/ Each of the last three arguments must be a value in the range 0 through 1000. When `init_color`
/ is used, all occurrences of that color on the screen immediately change to the new definition.

defs.name: init_pair
defs.value: pub fn init_pair(i16, i16, i16) -> i32
defs.docs: Changes the definition of a color-pair.

attributes.value: / Changes the definition of a color-pair.
/ It takes three arguments: the number of the color-pair to be redefined, and the new values of
/ the foreground and background colors. The pair number must be between 0 and `COLOR_PAIRS` - 1,
/ inclusive. The foreground and background must be between 0 and `COLORS()` - 1, inclusive. If the
/ color pair was previously initialized, the screen is refreshed, and all occurrences of that
/ color-pair are changed to the new definition.

defs.name: mouseinterval
defs.docs: Sets the timeout for a mouse click.

attributes.value: / Sets the timeout for a mouse click.
/ Sets the maximum time (in thousands of a second) that can elapse between press and release
/ events for them to be recognized as aclick. Use mouseinterval(0) to disable click resolution.
/ This function returns the previous interval value. Use mouseinterval(-1) to obtain the interval
/ without altering it. The default is one sixth of a second.

defs.name: mousemask
defs.docs: Set the mouse events to be reported.

attributes.value: / Set the mouse events to be reported.
/ By default, no mouse events are reported. The function will return a mask to indicate which of
/ the specified mouse events can be reported; on complete failure it returns 0. If oldmask is
/ non-NULL, this function fills the indicated location with the previous value of the given
/ window's mouse event mask.
/ As a side effect, setting a zero mousemask may turn off the mouse pointer; setting a nonzero
/ mask may turn it on. Whether this happens is device-dependent.

defs.name: keyname
defs.docs: Returns a character string corresponding to the key `code`.

attributes.value: / Returns a character string corresponding to the key `code`.
/ * Printable characters are displayed as themselves, e.g., a one-character string containing the
/   key.
/ * Control characters are displayed in the ^X notation.
/ * DEL (character 127) is displayed as ^?.
/ * Values above 128 are either meta characters (if the screen has not been initialized, or if
/   meta has been called with a TRUE parameter), shown in the M-X notation, or are displayed as
/   themselves. In the latter case, the values may not be printable; this follows the X/Open
/   specification.
/ * Values above 256 may be the names of the names of function keys.
/ * Otherwise (if there is no corresponding name) the function returns `None`, to denote an
/   error. X/Open also lists an "UNKNOWN KEY" return value, which some implementations return
/   rather than `None`.

defs.name: napms
defs.docs: Suspends the program for the specified number of milliseconds.

attributes.value: / Suspends the program for the specified number of milliseconds.

defs.name: newterm
defs.value: pub fn newterm(Option<&str>, FILE, FILE) -> ScrPtr
defs.docs:
A program that outputs to more than one terminal should use the newterm routine for each
 terminal instead of initscr.

attributes.value: / A program that outputs to more than one terminal should use the newterm routine for each
/ terminal instead of initscr.
/ A program that needs to inspect capabilities, so it can continue to
/ run in a line-oriented mode if the terminal cannot support a screen-oriented program, would also
/ use newterm. The routine newterm should be called once for each terminal. It returns a variable
/ of type `ScrPtr` which should be saved as a reference to that terminal.
/ (For the PDCurses backend it's just an alternative interface for initscr(). It always returns
/ SP, or NULL.)

defs.name: newwin
defs.value: pub fn newwin(i32, i32, i32, i32) -> Window
defs.docs: Creates a new window with the given number of lines, nlines and columns, ncols.

attributes.value: / Creates a new window with the given number of lines, nlines and columns, ncols.
/ The upper left corner of the window is at line begy, column begx. If nlines is zero, it
/ defaults to LINES - begy; ncols to COLS - begx. Create a new full-screen window by calling

defs.name: nl
defs.docs: Enables the translation of a carriage return into a newline on input.

attributes.value: / Enables the translation of a carriage return into a newline on input.
/ nonl() disables this. Initially, the translation does occur.

defs.name: nocbreak
defs.docs: Set nocbreak mode.

attributes.value: / Set nocbreak mode.
/ In cbreak mode, characters typed by the user are made available immediately, and erase/kill
/ character processing is not performed.  In nocbreak mode, typed characters are buffered until
/ a newline or carriage return. Interrupt and flow control characters are unaffected by this
/ mode.

defs.name: noecho
defs.docs: Disables echoing typed characters.

attributes.value: / Disables echoing typed characters.
/ Initially, input characters are echoed. Subsequent calls to echo() and noecho() do not flush
/ type-ahead.

defs.name: nonl
defs.docs: Disables the translation of a carriage return into a newline on input.

attributes.value: / Disables the translation of a carriage return into a newline on input.
/ nl() enables this. Initially, the translation does occur.

defs.name: noraw
defs.docs: Disable raw mode.

attributes.value: / Disable raw mode.
/ Raw mode is similar to cbreak mode, in that characters typed are immediately passed through to
/ the user program. The difference is that in raw mode, the INTR, QUIT, SUSP, and STOP characters
/ are passed through without being interpreted, and without generating a signal.

defs.name: raw
defs.docs: Enable raw mode.

attributes.value: / Enable raw mode.
/ Raw mode is similar to cbreak mode, in that characters typed are immediately passed through to
/ the user program. The difference is that in raw mode, the INTR, QUIT, SUSP, and STOP characters
/ are passed through without being interpreted, and without generating a signal.

defs.name: reset_prog_mode
defs.docs:
Restore the terminal to "program" (in curses) state. This is done
 automatically by endwin() and doupdate() after an endwin(), so this would normally not be
 called before.

attributes.value: / Restore the terminal to "program" (in curses) state. This is done
/ automatically by endwin() and doupdate() after an endwin(), so this would normally not be
/ called before.

defs.name: reset_shell_mode
defs.docs:
Restore the terminal to "shell" (not in curses) state. This is done automatically by
 endwin() and doupdate() after an endwin(), so this would normally not be called before.

attributes.value: / Restore the terminal to "shell" (not in curses) state. This is done automatically by
/ endwin() and doupdate() after an endwin(), so this would normally not be called before.

defs.name: resize_term
defs.docs: Attempts to resize the screen to the given size.

attributes.value: / Attempts to resize the screen to the given size.
/ `resize_term()` is effectively two functions: When called with nonzero values for nlines and
/ ncols, it attempts to resize the screen to the given size. When called with (0, 0), it merely
/ adjusts the internal structures to match the current size after the screen is resized by the
/ user. If you want to support user resizing, you should check for getch() returning `KEY_RESIZE`,
/ and/or call `is_termresized()` at appropriate times; if either condition occurs, call
/ `resize_term(0, 0)`. Then, with either user or programmatic resizing, you'll have to resize any
/ windows you've created.

defs.name: set_blink
defs.docs:
Toggles whether the `A_BLINK` attribute sets an actual blink mode (TRUE), or sets the background
 color to high intensity (FALSE).

attributes.value: / Toggles whether the `A_BLINK` attribute sets an actual blink mode (TRUE), or sets the background
/ color to high intensity (FALSE).
/ The default is platform-dependent (FALSE in most cases). It returns OK if it could set the
/ state to match the given parameter, ERR otherwise. Current platforms also adjust the value
/ of COLORS() according to this function -- 16 for FALSE, and 8 for TRUE.
/ (Only supported on Windows)

defs.name: set_term
defs.docs: Switches between different terminals.

attributes.value: / Switches between different terminals.
/ The screen reference new becomes the new current terminal. The previous terminal is returned by
/ the routine. This is the only routine which manipulates ScrPtr's; all other routines  affect
/ only the current terminal.
/ (Does nothing meaningful in PDCurses, but is included for compatibility with other curses
/ implementations.)

defs.name: set_title
defs.docs:
Sets the title of the window in which the curses program is running. This function may not do
 anything on some platforms. (Only supported on Windows)

attributes.value: / Sets the title of the window in which the curses program is running. This function may not do
/ anything on some platforms. (Only supported on Windows)

defs.name: start_color
defs.docs:
Initializes eight basic colors (black, red, green, yellow, blue, magenta, cyan,
 and white), and two global variables accessed through `COLORS()` and `COLOR_PAIRS()` (respectively defining the
 maximum number of colors and color-pairs the terminal is capable of displaying).

attributes.value: / Initializes eight basic colors (black, red, green, yellow, blue, magenta, cyan,
/ and white), and two global variables accessed through `COLORS()` and `COLOR_PAIRS()` (respectively defining the
/ maximum number of colors and color-pairs the terminal is capable of displaying).

defs.name: use_default_colors
defs.docs: Allows the use of -1 as a foreground or background color with `init_pair()`.

attributes.value: / Allows the use of -1 as a foreground or background color with `init_pair()`.
/ Calls `assume_default_colors(-1, -1);` -1 represents the foreground or background color that
/ the terminal had at startup.
